Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Raimkul

texts.en:
K. Raimkul is from the town of Istaravshan. He is 39 years old, married and has four children. Raimkul has always lived in the agricultural region of Istaravshan where he owns a small land and for the last 4 years he has worked as a farmer. He learned this skill from his father. 

On his land he cultivates potato, wheat and other vegetables together with the help of his elder sons. At the same time Raimkul uses his car to provide a taxi service, and also raises cattle. His car requires thorough repairs, which has prompted Ramikul to seek a second loan request through IMON International. This will allow him to purchase spare parts for his car, and earn more money to send his children to university.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts for his car

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa M. sells food supplies and fish which she buys from the fishermen, brings them home for processing and preservation, and then sends them to the market to sell at the Amoabin market near Cape Coast. Adjoa has received a junior high education. She is divorced and has six dependants. Adjoa has been selling fish and food supplies for about two years now. She is responsible for paying the children's school fees, rent, utility bills, and other financial expenses. Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy more food supplies and fish in larger quantities for processing and sales. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in the expansion of her trade in processed fish.

loans.use: To purchase more food supplies and fish in larger quantities for processing and sales

loans.name: Mariama Issa

texts.fr: Mariama Issa B. est une veuve qui a la charge familiale et scolaire de ses enfants. Elle veut poursuivre son activité de vente de divers produits alimentaires au marché où elle tient un étal. Elle projette ainsi d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mariama Issa B. is a widow who is responsible for the family and her children’s schooling. She wants to continue with her work selling various food items at the marketplace, where she has a stall. Thus, she plans on improving her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pursue her business selling various food items at the marketplace

loans.name: Uktam

texts.en:
N. Uktam is 41 years old and the father of four children. Uktam is a villager in Istaravshan in Northern Tajikistan. He and his wife are farmers who own a hectare of land to cultivate potato and rice. At the same time Uktam raises cattle. 

Uktam is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and seeds for planting. Uktam’s children are all studying at school. He hopes he can continue to provide for them so they will be able to receive an adequate education.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Seynabou

texts.fr: Seynabou D. est mariée et participe aux frais familiaux. Elle compte avec ce prêt renforcer son activité de vente de bois mort, huile de palme et jus de citron au marché où elle tient un étal. Elle pourra ainsi améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Seynabou D. is married and helps with the household expenses. With this loan, she would like to bolster her business, which consists of selling gathered wood, palm oil and lemon juice at the marketplace where she has a stall. Thus, she will be able to improve her family's living conditions.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her business of selling gathered wood

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en: Innocent E. is 36 years old and married with one child. He has a farm where he cultivates palm trees, pineapple, and cassava. Presently, he needs to do some clearing and also plant crops in the farm. Innocent is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN 30,000 to hire more hands for clearing and to do some planting as well. He says thanks to Kiva and all its lenders.

loans.use: For the clearing and planting of more crops on his farm

loans.name: Raqya Group

texts.en:
Rona is the group leader of Raqya group. There are four members in this group. All of them would like to receive a loan for his/her own business.

Rona and Raqya want a loan for her her beading business so she can buy necessary materials for her business. Shafeqa wants a loan for her son’s general store as he wants to enlarge his business. Sakhy Dad wants a loan for his general store to increase his inventory. With this loan they are can improve their businesses and support their families, thus making a better future for themselves and their families.

loans.use: To purchase more stock and enlarge their businesses

loans.name: Amenye

texts.en:
Pictured is 35 years old Amenye K. from Mbeya. She is married with two children, between the ages of 15 and 17. Amenye has been running a crops-selling business since 2002. Her business consists of purchasing maize and beans from wholesalers and then selling those items in retail. 

She works at the business for about five to eight hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her husband.  Amenye currently earns about 100USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 375USD in order to purchase beans and maize in bulk for reselling. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and the range of her business.  Amenye thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:	
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase beans and maize in bulk for reselling

loans.name: Nicholas Kweku

texts.en: Nicholas Kweku D. sells maize at the Nyankumasi market near Cape Coast. Nicholas Kweku has completed an education up to the junior high. He is married and has four dependants. His wife is a trader. Nicholas Kweku has been selling maize for about three years now. He is responsible for paying the children's school fees, rent, utility bills, and other financial expenses. His loan will be used to increase his capital which will enable him to increase the quantities of maize he sells. Nicholas Kweku hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest in the expansion of his trade in maize.

loans.use: To increase his capital to enable him to increase the quantities of maize he sells

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice G. is married and has four dependants. She has completed schooling through the primary level. Alice sells beans and groundnut which she distributes to her costumers. She also sells spices and other items at the Amoabin market near Cape Coast, which she has done for about a year now. Her husband is a farmer. Alice uses her income to support her husband in paying the rent, utility bills, and other basic expenses of the family. Alice will use the loan to increase her capital to buy more beans and groundnut in larger quantities to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Alice plans to reinvest in the expansion of her trade in groundnut and beans.

loans.use: To buy more beans and groundnut in larger quantities to sell

loans.name: Bellah

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 33 year-old Bellah M. from Mbeya. She is married with three children who are between the ages of four and 11.  Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependant because her parents have already passed away.

Bellah has been running a retail shop since 2008. She purchases items in whole sale bases, then sells them in retail bases. She works at the business for about 13-16 hours per day, seven days per week and employs one other worker. Bennah currently earns about 70USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 375USD in order to purchase more beans and rice in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the amount of stock.  Bellah thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more beans and rice in bulk

loans.name: George

texts.en: George K. sells agricultural chemicals at the Amoabin lorry park near Cape Coast. George has completed an education up to the junior high level. He is now married and has five dependants. His wife is a trader. George has been selling agricultural chemicals for about two years now. He is responsible for supporting his wife in paying the rent, utility bills, and other basic expenses of the family. George's loan will be used to increase his capital to enable him to increase the quantities of agricultural chemicals he sells. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest in the expansion of his trade in agricultural chemicals.

loans.use: To increase his capital to enable him increase the quantities of agricultural chemicals he sells

loans.name: Blandina

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 37 year-old Blandina M. from Mbeya. She is married with three children who are between the ages of one and 17. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent  because his parents are not in good condition.

Blandina has been running a business of “vitenge” (Tanzanian traditional clothes for women) and other goods since 1999. She works at the business for five to eight hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by one member of the family. Blandina currently earns about 200 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 600USD in order to expand the business by purchasing more vitenge in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of vitenge iso that she can continue reselling. Blandina thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To expand her by purchasing more vitenge in bulk

loans.name: Mapinduzi Group

texts.en:
Shakila O., age 30, is married with two children, ages 15 and 18. She sells juice and bites. She started this business five years ago and works daily from 8am until 11pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $207. 

This will be Shakila’s sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase the stock and improve her cafe and has repaid the loans successfully. She now hopes for a sixth loan to open a pharmacy. 

Shakila will share this loan with her loan group, Mapinduzi, which totals 20 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Shakila O. is in the back left in a dark dress.

loans.use: To build a pharmacy

loans.name: Neema A.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 50 year-old Neema S. from Mbeya. She is married with seven children who are between the ages of 13 and 30. 

Neema has been running a mgahawa business [local restaurant] since 2008. When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to visit. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough made from maize flour), plantains (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat and a variety of yummy sauces.

She works at the business for 13 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by one employee. Neema currently earns about 96USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 300USD in order to renovate a her business place. In the future, she plans to start a new business. Neema thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To renovate her business

loans.name: Sahib

texts.en: Sahib was born in 1955. He lives in Baku city and has worked the in construction supplies business for five years. Now he needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy construction supplies for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies

loans.name: Rovshan

texts.en: Rovshan was born in 1972. He lives in Baku city. He has been in the business of building houses for three years. Now he needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy the necessary supplies for building houses.

loans.use: To buy supplies for building houses

loans.name: Phelomina

texts.en:
Phelomina G. sells groceries such as biscuits, canned products and others at the Amoabin lorry park near Cape Coast. Phelomina has received no formal education. She is married and has 6 dependents. Her husband is a petty trader.

Phelomina has been selling groceries for some years now. She is responsible for helping her husband pay rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Her loan will be used to buy more groceries to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest for the expansion of her grocery business.

loans.use: to buy more groceries for re-sale

loans.name: David

texts.en: David U. is 42 years old and married with 6 children. David has a farm where he cultivates cassava and he says he needs to put all his children in school, that is why he needs to plant another farm to make more money to take care of his family. He is requesting the loan amount of N 25,000 to meet his goal. He says thanks to Kiva and all lenders.

loans.use: To plant crops on another farm

loans.name: Natavan

texts.en: Natavan is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, in the Kalbadjar region, and is settled in the town of Xirdalan. She was born in 1981 and is single. Three years ago she opened her general store. Now she needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy foodstuffs for improving her business.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena N. is 30-year-old woman. She is married and has four children. Three are schooling and the last-born is still breastfeeding. She lives with her husband in her matrimonial home at Koforidua, a suburb of Offinso, in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Abena, though she is young, is an achiever and a resourceful young woman. She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living.

Abena has been selling bananas and plantains in Koforidua market for more than six years now. She treks to surrounding villages in the central part of Ghana to purchase bulk stocks of bananas from the farmers and retails them to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to buy a lot of stock at any one time to make enough profit to support her family. Abena buys the unripe bananas in bulk and she covers them with plantain leaves in the bush. She leaves them there for a while so when they are ripe she goes for them and retails them to her customers. She wants to use part of the profit to pay for her kids' education.

With the loan, she wants to purchase a bulk supply of bananas to enable her to scale up her sales. She believes the loan would enable her to save more income to support her business growth. Abena belongs to a village bank called ‘Eye Awurade’ which means "Is God". She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more to help her husband in taking care of the household.

loans.use: To purchase bunches of bananas and plantains

loans.name: Nadejda

texts.en: Nadejda was born in 1952. She lives in Baku city. She has 10 years of experience in her consulting business. Now she needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy a computer for improving her business.

loans.use: To buy a computer

loans.name: Protea Group

texts.en:
Alawi H., age 48, is married with five children, ages 21, 19, 16, 14 and 10. He also cares for his mother who is a widow. He has a fruit business and also works as a watchman in a private company. He started his business in 2007 and works daily from 10am until 6pm. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around US$ 30.

This will be Alawi’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He will use this loan to buy more fruit for sale. Alawi will share this loan with his loan group, Protea, which totals 20 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Alawi is 1st from right, front row.

loans.use: Increase the inventory for his fruit business

loans.name: Super Group

texts.en:
Ferdinand sells clothing, watches, necklaces and school stationery. Before moving to Kinshasa, he taught in the Equator province in the DRCongo.  In 1987 he started his first business with a working capital of US$ 15. He was selling sugar, salt, soaps, toilet paper, candles, matches and so on in his village. From 1987 to 1997, his business was prosperous and he increased his working capital to US$ 400. 

From 1997 to 2000, the Equator province was invaded by the war from eastern Congo, and people were forced to leave their homes. He and his family moved to Mbandaka, the main town of the province. From 2000 to 2003, he continued running his business there with restriction due to the war. In 2004 he fell sick and was very often hospitalized for almost a year. He suffered from malaria and bronchitis. He used almost all of his business working capital for medical care. 

After recovering, Ferdinand decided to change his business and started to sell lamp oil in 2005 once again with a working capital of US$ 15. He worked very hard, and with good management he increased his working capital to US$ 300 in 2007. After learning through a friend about Hope’s loan program, he decided to join one of its groups in the same year. 

Ferdinand has already received five loans from Hope that he repaid correctly. With his next loan he plans to extend his business by adding others items such as bracelets and earrings. His dream is to purchase second-hand appliances from Europe and sell them in Kinshasa. Ferdinand is 52 years old and a father of 5 children between the ages 13 and 27 of whom four go to school and the oldest is independent. Ferdinand runs his business in the northeastern part of Kinshasa.

loans.use: To extend his business by purchasing other items for which there is a demand in his area

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Ambrose

texts.en: Ambrose E. is 59 years old and married with 14 children. He is a farmer; he cultivates cassava and yams which he uses to take care of his family. His wife also farms. He needs money to cultivate more cassava. He is requesting the loan amount of N 30,000 cultivate more cassava. He says thanks to Kiva and all lenders.

loans.use: To cultivate more cassava

loans.name: Vafa

texts.en: Vafa (her husband is pictured) is a mother of two children, a boy and a girl. She was born in 1976. Her husband has run a taxi business for five years. Now they need a loan of 950 AZN to buy spare parts for improving their business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is a 60-year-old entrepreneur. She is divorced with four children; they have all graduated from their apprenticeship training in various disciplines such as hairdressing, carpentry, etc. She believes in hard work and dedication as the primary antidote to poverty and for that matter, she is very serious with her business.

She sells foodstuffs like plantains. She started this business three years ago in Koforidua, but realized that business was slow. She then relocated to the next town which is Abofour and has remained in this business since then. Through this, Mary has been very resourceful for her family. She wants to use the loan to buy a larger supply of plantains to serve her customers throughout the season, especially in the face of increasing prices due to the current food crisis in the country. She believes with the loan she can buy bunches of plantains direct from the farmers, avoiding middlemen who retail to her at high price.

Mary belongs to a village bank called ‘Chance’. She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy bunches of plantains to restock her business

loans.name: Rotari

texts.en: Ms. Rotari R. is 45 years old and lives in the Falesti district with her three children. Her children are in school and she pays for their school materials and clothing in addition to all of their living expenses. For the past 5 years she has sold fruit and vegetables at the wholesale market in the town of Falesti. She would like a loan of $950 to increase her sales volume. R. is a responsible and energetic businesswoman, and MicroInvest is sure that these capabilities will help her succeed.

loans.use: BLVC-08.09.PT

loans.name: Exaucée Group

texts.en:
Mado is 45 years old and the mother of 6 children between the ages of 13 and 28, of whom three go to school and three  are already independent. Mado runs a cement store and also sells 10kg sacks of corn flour. She has been in business since 1994. She began her business with US$ 60, selling palm oil from 1994 to 1995. In 1996, her business slowed down because of the deterioration of her health. 

In 1998, Mado decided to change her business by starting to sell rice, semolina and vegetable oil. Most of her working capital was focused on semolina because of the profit it was generating. Unfortunately, in 1999 many companies closed in DRCongo due to the war and insecurity, including those that were producing Mado’s goods. So her business regressed until 2007 when she re-launched it, offering new types of products. She began selling women’s slippers, vegetable oil, and corn flour. 

After learning through her friend about Hope’s loan program, she decided to join one of its groups in May 2008. Mado has already received two loans from Hope that she repaid correctly. Currently, her working capital is about $170. With her next loan she is planning to purchase 28 10kg sacks of corn flour to increase the inventory of her business. Mado’s dream is to do corn and manioc farming and be a provider of those products in her area. She runs her business in the northern and most populated area of Kinshasa.

loans.use: To purchase 28 10kg sacks of corn flour

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Uti

texts.en: Uti T. is 35 years old and married with 6 children. He is a farmer; he cultivates cassava. Presently he plans to cultivate another cassava farm, which will cost him some money. He is requesting the loan amount of N 30,000 to meet his goal. He says thanks to Kiva and all lenders.

loans.use: To cultivate another cassava farm

loans.name: Elsavar

texts.en: Elsavar was born in 1987. He is single and lives in Baku city. This young man has run his general store for three years. Now he needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy foodstuffs for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Djafar

texts.en: Djafar was born in 1963. He lives in Baku city. He has been in the manufacturing business for 10 years. Now he needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy the necessary materials for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy materials for improving his business

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence K. is 40 years old. She is married with four children. She lives with her husband in her matrimonial home at Koforidua, a suburb of Offinso, in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Florence is an achiever and a resourceful woman. She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living.

Florence has been selling bananas at Koforidua market for six years now, to support her family. She treks to surrounding villages in the central part of Ghana to purchase bulk stocks of banana from farmers and retails to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to buy enough stock at any one time to make enough profit to support her family. Florence buys unripe banana in bulk and she covers them with plantain leaves in the bush. She leaves them there for a while and when they are ripe she goes for them and retails them to her customers.

With the loan, she wants to purchase a bulk supply of bananas to enable her to scale up her sales. She believes the loan would enable her to save more income to support her business growth. Florence belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame Bekyere’; in a literal translation this means "God will show". She hopes to receive GHS 1000 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her save more to help her husband in taking care of the household.

loans.use: To purchase bunches of bananas for re-sale

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William O. is 47 years old.  He is married and has seven children. His first born is in the senior high school, and the rest are all in the primary school. William is very popular in his area because of his hard work and his dedication to work. He is a commercial taxi driver and also sells food items like maize. He has been in this business for over two years now. William said he started this business when demands for maize became very high in the surrounding communities. William buys his goods from the farmers in far away communities and retails to food vendors and treks the remaining to the big cities. He is also a taxi driver but, for now, he drives someone else's car. He is looking forward to buying his own car when business progresses. William wants a loan to increase his working capital so that his dream of buying his own car and goods in bulk can be achieved. In this way, he can supply to a large number of customers to increase his market size and his profit margin.

William belongs to a group called ‘Nyame Akwan’ which  means God’s way. He also hope to receive a loan of $300 to make business progress by restocking his inventory. This would enable him save more to support the wife and to take care of their children's educational needs.

loans.use: William wants the loan to buy cereals in bulk such as maize and to maintain his taxi cab.

loans.name: Lyudmila

texts.en: Lyudmila was born in 1950. She has been in the education business for 15 years. Now she needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy a computer for improving her work. She lives in Baku city. Lyudmila is a teacher at a school. She is pictured with a student.

loans.use: to buy a computer

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph O. is 64 years old and married with 4 children. He has a farm where he cultivates cassava. He has not cultivated the entire piece of land because of funding. He is requesting the loan amount of 30,000 to cultivate more cassava. He says thanks to Kiva and all lenders.

loans.use: To cultivate more cassava

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort A. is a 44 year old woman. She is married and has given birth to five children. Two of her children are learning a  trade, one sadly passed away and the others are in school. She lives with her husband in her matrimonial home at Koforidua, a suburb of Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Comfort is an achiever; a resourceful woman who loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living. 
 
Comfort has traded in the sale of banana and cassava in Koforidua market for more than five years. She treks to surrounding villages to purchase bulk stock of banana and cassava from the farmers and sells retail to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to buy enough  stock from the farmers to make enough profit to support her family. She wants to use part of the profit to support her children's education.
  
With a loan of $750, Comfort wants to purchase bulk supplies of banana and plantain to enable her to increase her sales. She believes the loan would enable her to save more income to grow her business and support her family. Comfort belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame Bekyere’ which means "God will show".

loans.use: To purchase bulk supplies of banana and cassava.

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: Akosua N. has been trading in the local market of Koforidua, a suburb of Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana, where she stays with her family. She is 22 years old with two children, one of whom is in school and the other, a baby. She is single and still lives with her parents. Akousa dropped out of school for financial reasons. It has been her dream to go back to the classroom. She is a busy trader who sells rice grain, plantains, pepper, onions and other food stuffs in the market. She does not have sufficient working capital to run her business.  With a loan of $350,  Akousahe believes her business will grow and that will enable her to increase her savings so that she can go to school this year. She would be grateful for that assistance. Akosua belongs to a village bank called ‘Nhyira Mma’ which means "Blessed Children".

loans.use: To purchase increased stock of palm oil, tin tomatoes, yams, onions, beans, maize, dried fish etc

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
Frank O. is 31 years old. He lives in Benin City, in the Edo State of Nigeria. He is a farmer; more specifically, he cultivates cassava on his farm.

He would like to expand his business, so he plans to cultivate cassava on another farm, but doing so would cost approximately 50,000 NGN and thus requires an infusion of capital . As such, he is requesting a loan in the amount of $225 (30,000 NGN) to cultivate another cassava farm. In turn, he will be able to take great care of his family. He thanks Kiva and all lenders for their support.

loans.use: To cultivate a second cassava farm

loans.name: Tatu N.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 36 years old Tatu M. from Mbeya. She is married with three children who are between the ages of three and 10. 

Tatu has been running a business selling used clothes since 1997. Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers. These retailers then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because of their low cost. Furthermore, western or modern clothing is becoming more appealing Some argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress, however the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

She works at the business for nine to 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by one employee and one family member. Tatu currently earns about 60USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 375USD in order to purchase more used clothes in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of clothes and to open another business. Tatu thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes in bulk

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary D.  is married and the mother of six children. Through hard work, Mary has supported her eldest to complete a training program in tailoring, one is in the senior high school while her other children are is still in the primary level in school. Mary resides in Offinso with her family. 
She is a food vendor who sells kenkey in her neighborhood. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and eaten with hot pepper and fried fish. She has many customers since many Ghanaians enjoy kenkey for breakfast, lunch and supper. In addition to her food, Mary also sells bananas in the market square where she lives. She has been in the food business for the past 14years. Mary hopes to receive a loan of $425 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Zulfa J.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 31 year old Zulfa M. from Mbeya. She is married with 2 children, ages 8 and 10 respectively. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent because her parents' life situation is not good; in addition, she is a student.

Zulfa has been running a medical shop since 1997. She works at the business for 5-8 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Zulfa currently earns about 110USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 600USD in order to purchase more medicine in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of medicine. Zulfa thanks you for your support!

One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Purchasing medicine in bulk

loans.name: Felista

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 30 year-old Felista C. from Mwanza. She is single with two children who are four years old. Felista has been running a genge business since 2006. Her business consists of selling onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice, banana and dried fish. She works at the business for 16 hours per day, seven days per week and is assisted by her husband. 

Felista currently earns about 80 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 250 USD in order to buy additional inventories of onions, groundnuts, banana and tomatoes. In the future, she plans to increase her stocks. Felista thanks you for her support!

The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy onions, groundnuts, banana and tomatoes for her business

loans.name: Rabiha

texts.en: Rabiha, 35, lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with her husband and their five children. Rabiha owns a household electrical appliances shop. She is requesting a loan of $1000 USD from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her shop. This is the first time that Rabiha has requested a loan. Her clients are her family members, friends, and neighbors.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her shop

loans.name: Gherman

texts.en: Gherman S. is from the Calarasi district. Gherman is married and has two children. Her husband left the country 5 years ago to look for work abroad with the hope that he would be paid much better. But S. remained here with her children and she is responsible for maintaining the household. S.'s children often help their mother with some of the farming work. She would like a loan from MicroInvest to buy seeds and expand her business of growing vegetables and grain.

loans.use: to buy vegetable and grain seeds

loans.name: Mouhamad

texts.en:
Mouhamad, 45, lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Mouhamad has owned a bakery for 30 years. He sells mankoucheh, which looks like a folded pizza. The most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese), and lahm bi ajin (chopped meat). You can eat mankoucheh anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Mouhamad is requesting a loan of $1000 USD from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials for his bakery. This is the first time that Mouhamad has requested a loan.
Mouhamad does his work well. His clients are his friends and neighbors. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for his bakery

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad, 25, lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon with his wife and their child. Ahmad has been working as a car painter for eight years. He is requesting a loan of $1200 USD from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is his second loan; he repaid the first loan on time. His previous loan helped him improve his business. His clients are his family members, friends, and neighbors. Ahmad decided to paint cars because he wanted to work independently and improve his income. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Tto purchase tools for his work

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 51 year-old Eliza K. from Mwanza. She is married with four children who are between the ages of 18 and 30. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two orphans.

Eliza has been running a beverage business since 2006. She sells beers, water and soda. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her husband. Eliza currently earns about 200USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to buy more beers such as Kilimanjaro, tusker, safari lager, the kick, reds, Bavaria and Serengeti. In the future, she plans to open a new business. Eliza thanks you for her support!

loans.use: To buy more beers such as Kilimanjaro, tusker, safari lager, the kick, reds, Bavaria and Serengeti

loans.name: Bachar

texts.en:
Bachar, 33, lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Bachar has been a taxi driver for eight years. He is requesting a loan of $1000 USD from Al Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his car. This is the first time that Bachar has requested a loan.
His clients can be anybody. He decided to become a taxi driver because he wanted to work independently.

loans.use: To do maintenance work on his car

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en:
Abdallah is a 48 year old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their eight children. 
Abdallah has been working in agriculture for twenty years. He produces cucumber, lettuce and other vegetables in the green house. He has requested a loan of 1200 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase fertilizer and cucumber seeds. This is the first time that Abdallah has requested a loan.His clients are the markets. 
Abdallah decided on doing this business because it is the family business and he has been working in it since he was young

loans.use: Abdallah will use the loan to purchase fertilizer and cucumber seeds.

loans.name: Cresensia

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 32-year old Cresensia O. from Mwanza. She is married with three children who are between the ages of three and 10. Additionally, she is also mother to one orphan.

Cresensia has been running a furniture business since 2007. She sells beds, chairs and tables. She works at the business for eight hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her husband. Cresensia currently earns about 100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to buy 40 pieces of timber so that she can continue to make furniture. In the future, she plans to increase her timber stock. Cresensia thanks you for her support!

loans.use: To buy pieces of timber to make furniture for her business

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 55 year old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their seven children. 
Ali has been working as a mason for twenty years and he has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan.
His clients can be anybody. Ali decided on doing this business because of his experience.

loans.use: Ali will use the loan to purchase tools for his work.

loans.name: Chama

texts.en:
Chama is a 49 year old woman who lives in the Bekaa with her husband and their four children. 
Chama has owned a grocery store for two years. She also sells sweets. Chama requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her store. This is the first time that Chama has requested a loan. 
Her clients are her friends and neighbors. 
In the future, Chama plans to expand her business.

loans.use: Chama will use the loan to purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 27 year-old Veronica M. from Mwanza. She is married with two children who are between the ages of one and four. Additionally, she is is mother to one orphan.

Veronica has been running a tailoring business since 2006. She sells clothes mainly for women. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, five days per week and is assisted by her husband. Veronica currently earns about 100 USD a month from her business. 

Now, she is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase vitambaa (material), vitenge (a traditional Tanzanian cloth with wax print) and kanga (printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides). She plans to use these materials to design clothing mainly for women. In the future, she plans to increase her stocks. Veronica thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchases vitambaa (material), vitenge (a traditional Tanzanian cloth with wax print), and kanga (printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides) to make them into women's clothing

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is single. She offers retail items such as groceries, jewelry and fancy goods in a local grocery market in Stryi, Western Ukraine. Irina owns a kiosk and a vending stall. Irina launched her business on the advice of her mother who supported her from the very beginning. Irina has set a reasonable pricing policy and that became one of the reasons why many clients come to her for groceries and other inventory. Irina has been in this business only for 3 years. She already has about 25,000 Grivnas in inventory.

Irina has employed three vendors who work for her. This time she is hoping to get a loan for 9,000 Grivnas to further develop her business. Irina is very sharp and learns fast. She always listens to the advice of other entrepreneurs who are more experienced and have been in business longer. We believe her managerial abilities and focused attitude will secure prompt loan repayment and further success of her trade.

loans.use: To develop her business

loans.name: Mhamad

texts.en:
Mhamad is a 36 year old man who lives in the Bekaa. He has been working as a furniture painter for fifteen years. Mhamad has requested a loan of 800 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase painting tools. This is his second cycle and he has always paid on time.
His previous loan helped him improve his business. His clients are his friends and neighbors. 
Mhamad decided on doing this business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: Mhamad will use the loan to purchase painting tools.

loans.name: Upendo S.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 29 year-old Upendo I. from Mbeya. She is married with two children who are between the ages of seven and 12. Upendo has been running a clothes shop since 2007. 

She works at the business for nine to 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her husband. Upendo currently earns about 150 USD a month from her business. 

She is requesting a loan of 525 USD in order to purchase more clothes in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase more clothes for reselling. Upendo thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase additional inventories of clothing for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Mohamad will use the loan to purchase merchandise for his shop.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 20 year old man who lives in the Bekaa. Mohamad has owned a clothing shop for four years. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. 
His clients can be anybody. Mohamad decided on doing his business because it was his father business and his father has owned the store for over twenty two years, as well as his experience in sales. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Mohamad will use the loan to purchase new games for his shop.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 42 year-old Mary K. from Mwanza She is married with five children who are between the ages of 15 and 25 years old.
 
Mary has been running a grocery business since 2005. She sells a number of food items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice, cabbages, spinach and dried fish. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, six days per week. Mary currently earns about 100 USD a month from her business. 

She is currently requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to buy more fruits, cabbages, spinach, tomatoes and onions. In the future, she plans to increase her stocks. Mary thanks you for her support!

loans.name: Teofila

texts.es: A sus 48 años, Teófila ha luchado mucho para tener una buena vida, vive con su esposo en un cuarto alquilado y anhela con todas sus fuerzas tener un futuro prometedor. Ella es una muy buena vendedora de pan, hace los panes más deliciosos del mercado Laykakota (Mercado muy conocido de la ciudad de Puno), le gusta conversar con sus vecinas, pero detesta vender en los días de lluvia, puesto que su mercadería termina mojada, ella es conciente que para salir adelante tiene que trabajar mucho y ya lleva 10 años en este cansado trabajo. Para el futuro quiere tener una tienda donde vender sus panes y otros productos, además brindarles mayores comodidades a sus clientes, no decae en su afán de sobresalir en la vida y tiene la esperanza de que si se esfuerza mucho lo logrará. Siendo éste el segundo préstamo al que accede en MFP, se siente con la responsabilidad de cancelar todas sus cuotas, es por eso que todos los días ahorra un poco de sus ventas, además que tiene una responsabilidad con su banco comunal. Teófila utilizará todo el dinero del préstamo en la compra de ingredientes para sus panes, comprará azúcar, harina, levadura, etc.
texts.en:
At 48 years old, Teófila has fought to have a good life. She lives with her husband in a rented room, and has longed with all her power to have a promising future. She is a successful bread salesperson, making the most delicious breads in the Laykakota Market (a well-known market in the city of Puno).

She likes to converse with her neighbors, but she hates to sell her breads when it's raining, because the market always ends up getting wet. She knows that to succeed she needs to work very hard and she already has 10 years of experience in this tiring business. In the future, she'd like to have a store where she could sell her breads and other products, and also offer more amenities to her clients. Her enthusiasm for succeeding in life does not fade, and she has hope that with hard work, she will achieve success.

As this is her second loan with MFP (a Kiva partner) and because she has a relationship with her community bank, Teófila feels the responsibility to repay each of her installments. Because of this, she saves a little of the profits from her sales each day. She will use all of the money from the loan to buy ingredients for her breads: sugar, flour, yeast, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients to make bread

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Mohamad will use the loan to purchase merchandise for his shop.

loans.name: Alla

texts.en:
Alla is a widow. She raises two teenage daughters, 16 and 13, on her own. Alla’s family is from Kahovka, a small town in the south-east of Ukraine. There are very few job opportunities in this region of the country. Alla faced that hard reality two years ago. This is when she decided to launch her own small business selling Avon cosmetics. Alla says this type of business allows her to manage her time and provide for her family as well.

Alla is requesting a loan of 5,000 Grivnas to develop her business and profits as a result. Presently, she has 3,000 in turnover capital. Her monthly net profit amounts to 1,500 Grivnas. Alla does not want to stop where she is. She believes that current financial assistance will be beneficial for her business by keeping it competitive and promoting growth so that it will continue to provide necessary income for her and the family.

loans.use: To generate additional profit

loans.name: Chafik

texts.en:
Chafik is a 30 year old man who lives in the Bekaa. Chafik owns a mini market store which was started by his grandfather and has been in the family for 55 years. Chafik has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. This is the first time that Chafik has requested a loan.
His clients are people from his region. Chafik decided on doing this business because it is a family business. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Chafik will use the loan to purchase merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Pictured here is 26 year-old Rose L. from Mwanza. She is married with one four year-old child.
 
Rose has been running a small shop since 2005. She sells a number of common household and grocery items such as soda, water, sugar, soaps, tealeaves, eggs, maize flours, wheat flours and fitness books. She works at the business for 13 hours per day, seven days per week and is assisted by her husband. 

Rose currently earns about 200 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to buy additional stocks of soda, sugar, wheat flours and fitness books. In the future, she plans to increase the stocks of her business. Rose thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks of soda, sugar, wheat flours and fitness books

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 25 year old man who lives in the Bekaa. Ali has owned a owned a mini market store for a year. He has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan.
His clients are people from his area. In the future, Ali plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Ali will use the loan to purchase merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Ghada

texts.en:
Ghada is a 31 year old woman who lives in the Bekaa. Ghada has owned a grocery store for five years. She is an active women, who also sells clothes and flowers. She has requested a loan of 700 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase fish because she wants to start a new business. 
This is her third cycle and she has always paid on time.
Her previous loans helped her diversify her merchandise and improve her business. Her clients are people from her region.

loans.use: Ghada will use the loan to purchase fish because she wants to start a new business.

loans.name: Mehsna

texts.en:
Mehsna is a 52 year old woman who lives in the Bekaa with her husband and their seven children. She has owned a grocery store for five years. She also sells sweets and mankoucheh. A mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza, most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Mehsna has requested a loan of 700 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her store. This is the first time that Mehsna has requested a loan.
Her clients are her friends and neighbors. In the future, she plans on expanding her business and opening a restaurant.

loans.use: Mehsna will use the loan to purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Omo

texts.en: Omo I. is a 48-year-old married woman with 10 children.  To earn a living, she sells palm oil.  She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $350 (50,000 NGN) in order to expand her inventory; in other words, she would use the loan proceeds to purchase more palm oil for resale purposes.  She thanks Kiva and all lenders for their support.

loans.use: To increase her inventory by purchasing additional palm oil

loans.name: Erika

texts.en:
Erika is married and raises two kids. Her family lives in Korolyovo. Erika sells souvenirs and gifts in one of the local markets. She has been in the trade for 3 years. Favorable location of her vending kiosk and few competitors in the field provide good potential for growth of Erika’s business. Currently, she has about 50,000 Grivnas in inventory. Her average monthly income is about 6,000 Grivnas.

Erika is very inventive. She manages to keep her business running smoothly even amidst the worst economic conditions. She balances reasonable prices, despite rate increases, and a variety of inventory that she offers for sale in her kiosk. Erika is requesting a loan of 5,000 Grivnas to increase her turnover capital. She believes that having this additional capital will help her minimize her sales risk and provide further stable financial support for her family. Moreover, it will help Erika get closer to her ultimate goal of expanding her trade one day.

loans.use: To increase turnover capital

loans.name: Iad

texts.en:
Iad is a 33 year old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their three children. He has been working as a taxi van driver for ten years. Iad has requested a loan of 1200 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his van and pay the school tuition fees for his children. He has had loans with Al Majmoua previously and he has always paid on time.
His previous loans helped him improve his financial situation.

loans.use: Iad will use the loan to do some maintenance work on his van and pay the school tuition to his children.

loans.name: Yaneth

texts.es: Yaneth de 27 años, vive en su casa propia con su única hija Katia de 6 añitos, comparte la casa con sus hermanas, las cuales la apoyan para que salga adelante. Sin dejarse vencer por la adversidad, Yaneth vende todos los días de manera ambulatoria sus gorritas y sombreros, a lado de su pequeña hija, quien es el motivo principal para todo su sacrificio y es que Yaneth quiere darle unos buenos estudios y una vida digna. A ella le gusta vender sus productos y sobre todo ganar plata y para lograr su meta, no le importa quedarse vendiendo bajo la lluvia, en sus 8 años en este negocio a sabido ganarse la vida y espera que con el tiempo pueda tener un puesto mejor implementado. Lo que más desea es sacar a su hija adelante y darle lo que ella nunca pudo tener. Es el primer préstamo de Yaneth con MFP y espera no fallar en los pagos de sus cuotas, está muy comprometida con su banco comunal y no quiere causarles problemas a las socias que lo integran. Con el dinero solicitado comprará mayor cantidad de mercadería, invertirá todo el monto en incrementar los productos de su negocio.
texts.en:
Yaneth, 27 years old, lives in her own home with her only child, Katia, who is 6. They share the house with Yaneth's sisters, who support her as she tries to improve her life. Not allowing herself to be brought down by adversity, Yaneth sells caps and hats every day as a street vendor alongside her small daughter, who is the reason for all of Yaneth's sacrifices and for whom she wants to secure a good education and a dignified life.

She enjoys selling her products, and above all likes earning money, and to achieve her goal, she doesn't even mind making her sales in the rain. In her 8 years in this business, she has learned how to make a living, she hopes that with time she will be able to have a well-equipped stand to sell her products. What she wants the most is to help her daughter succeed and to give her daughter that which she was never able to have herself.

This is Yaneth's first loan with MFP and she hopes not to miss any of her repayments. She is very much obliged to her community bank and she doesn't want to cause any problems for the members. With the money she seeks, she will buy more merchandise, investing the entire amount in increasing her inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her inventory

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Mariama A. is a 50 year old woman. She is married and has six children. Three are in  school and the rest are traders in the market. She lives with her husband in her matrimonial home at Koforidua, a suburb of Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Mariama  is an achiever and a resourceful woman to her family. She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living. 

Mariama has traded in bananas, oranges and plantain sales in the Koforidua market for more than eight years now. She treks to surrounding villages in the central part of Ghana to purchase bulk stocks of bananas, oranges and plantains from the farmers and then sells them retail to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to pick enough stock to make enough profit to support her family. She buys unripe bananas in bulk and she covers them with plantain leaves in the bush. They will be there for awhile so when they are ripe she can go for them and sell them to her customers.  With a loan of $375 she wants to purchase bulk supplies of bananas, oranges and plantains to enable her to increase her sales. She wants to use part of the profit to support her children's education. Mariama belongs to a village bank called ‘Nhyira Mma’ which means "Blessed Children".

loans.use: To purchase bunch supplies of  bananas, oranges and plantains.

loans.name: Paullina

texts.en: Paullina B. is a 36-year-old married woman with two children.  She lives in Edo State, Nigeria, where she sells beef to earn a living.  Indeed, she has been in this line of business for many years, so she has considerable experience.  She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $675 (100,000 NGN) to purchase more beef for resale purposes.  She thanks Kiva and all lenders for their support.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional beef

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es: Maritza tiene 41 años, vive con sus dos hijos en su casa propia, ella es una buena madre de familia, siempre se preocupa por el bienestar de sus hijos y es que desea darles lo que ella no pudo tener. Comienza su negocio de venta de cosméticos visitando a sus clientes, es una vendedora muy persistente y convincente, disfruta de hablar con ellas y aconsejarles sobre lo que mejor le quedará a su rostro, su negocio es muy rentable ya que cuenta con una amplia cartera de clientes. Lo más difícil es cobrar, ya que no siempre sus clientes tienen plata para pagarle, pero con los 3 años de experiencia que tiene, se las arregla para que le paguen completito todas sus ventas, ella quiere poner su puesto de cosméticos donde pueda vender más cómoda y sin la necesidad de ir casa por casa. Con su primer préstamo, Maritza quiere hacer crecer su negocio, es por eso que desea pagar a tiempo todas sus cuotas para poder acceder a otro préstamo, además sabe que cuenta con el apoyo de su banco comunal. Con el dinero solicitado comprará más cosméticos, y con eso espera incrementar las ventas en su negocio.
texts.en:
Maritza is 41 years old and lives with her two children in her own home. She is a good mother, always worrying about the well-being of her children, and she wants to give them all that she couldn't have herself.

She began her cosmetics sales business by visiting her customers. She is a very persistent and convincing salesperson, and she enjoys talking with her customers and giving advice about what would look best on their faces. Her business is very profitable as she can count on a robust portfolio of customers. The most difficult is to charge for her products as her clients don't always have the funds to pay her. But in her 3 years' experience, she has arranged to be paid in full for all of her sales. She would like to locate her cosmetics sales business where she can sell them more comfortably, without needing to go door-to-door.

With her first loan, Maritza wants to grow her business, and wants to repay all of her installments on time, so that she can receive an additional loan. She knows she can also count on the support of her communal bank. With this loan, she will buy more cosmetics and hopes to increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Lokumu Group

texts.en:
Jeanine is 39 years old and the mother of 2 children, aged 21 and 23, who are in school. Jeanine operates a general boutique in Mbinza, the western part of Kinshasa. She sells sugar, rice, milk, soaps, beauty cream, salt, toilet papers, candles, matches, and so on. She has been in business since 2000, and her beginning capital was $200. With determination, good management, and the profit generated from her business, the working capital increased to $500 in 2002.

When the landlord decided to sell the place where Jeanine used to rent, she had to move her business somewhere else, but the business did not make enough profit as it did at the previous location. In 2007, with $600 as working capital, Jeanine decided to change the business. She started selling bananas. She liked that business because it was making $110 of profit per week. She opened a banana store, buying them in Lower Congo province and selling them in Kinshasa. Although the business was profitable, Jeanine’s health was deteriorating due to painful and hard work which caused her to fall sick often. She began suffering from backache and other medical problems. As she had already acquired solid experience in her general boutique, she and her family decided to change the business by re-launching it in January 2008, in a different business area. In September 2008, Jeanine joined one of Hope’s groups called “Lokumu”. With the loan she received from Hope, she bought packaging materials that are needed in the area. Her business makes $210 of profit per month. Currently, her working capital is $1100.

loans.use: To purchase packaging materials that are needed in the area

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing C. is a 28-year-old married woman.  She is a hair stylist, but she also sells hair cream, hair extensions, and women's clothes to generate additional income.  She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $675 (100,000 NGN) to purchase more goods (i.e., hair cream, hair extensions, and women's clothing) for resale purposes.  She thanks Kiva and all lenders for their support.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional materials for her salon (hair cream and extensions) and additional clothes to resell

loans.name: Dunas

texts.en: Dunas V. is 50 years old and works with her husband growing fruit and vegetables, which they sell at the market in the Cahul district. They have sold vegetables for 5 years. During the winter, they buy produce wholesale and resell it, but when it is warm enough, they farm their arable land in the village of Brinza and produce potatoes, melons, onions, cabbage and tomatoes. V. would like a loan from MicroInvest to buy seeds and vegetables in order to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy seeds and vegetables

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia T. is a 48 year old woman. She is divorced and has six children. One child is in school whiles the rest are taking care of themselves. She lives with her last born and her granddaughter in Koforidua, a suburb of Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Afia is an achiever and a resourceful woman. She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living. 

Afia trades fruits such as bananas by the road of Koforidua where she has lived for 10 years. She treks to surrounding villages to purchase bulk stocks of bananas from the farmers and sells them retail to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to buy enough stock to make enough profit to support her family. With a loan of $750, Afia wants to purchase bulk supplies of banana products to enable her to increase business growth. She believes the loan would enable her to save more income to support her family She also wants to use part of the profit to support her child's education. Afia belongs to a village bank called "Nso Nyame ye" which means "with God all things are possible".

loans.use: To purchase bulk supplies of bananas.

loans.name: Rabih

texts.en: Rabih is a 26-year-old man, living in Btibyat in Mount Lebanon. He opened a telephone and mobile shop in 2008, after working in a similar shop for three years. Rabih found out that there is a lot of potentiA. growth in his village; therefore he is requesting $1,200 in order to buy more inventory to satisfy his clients' needs.

loans.use: Buy more inventory

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 41-year-old married man with three children living in Bazourieh, southern Lebanon. He has been working in house-painting since 1990, when he learned from his father this profession. After taking several loans from Ameen, he improved his business and increased his client base. Today, Hussein wants to borrow $1,000 in order to buy new tools for better quality work.

loans.use: Buy new tools

loans.name: Bola

texts.en: Bola O. is a 35-year-old married woman with three children.  She lives in Ogbomosho, in the Oyo state of Nigeria.  To earn a living, she is a hair dresser, and she proudly states that she provides her customers with lovely hair styles.  At the same time, she also sells hair extensions and hair cream to generate additional income.  She is now seeking a loan in the amount of $350 (50,000 NGN) to purchase more hair extensions, hair cream, and a hair dryer.

loans.use: To improve her salon by purchasing a hair dryer and to expand her business by purchasing additional products for resale

loans.name: Ciobanu

texts.en: Ciobanu N. is 37 years old. She lives in the Cimislia district and grows grain and vegetables. Her neighbors also work in agriculture but they recognize that N. works hardest and has the richest harvest. She has three children who are students in Chisinau City. N. is determined that they attend university and to reach this goal she would like to expand her business with a loan from MicroInvest. With the loan, she plans to purchase more seeds and increase her yield of vegetables, which will boost her profit.

loans.use: To buy vegetable and grain seeds for farming

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 38-year-old married man with three children, living in Borj Al Shamali camp, southern Lebanon. He has worked as a construction worker for 15 years, and after taking several loans from Ameen, he bought new tools, and a car that he uses for moving from one site to another. Today, Ahmad wants to borrow $1,000 in order to fix his car, which is essential in his profession.

loans.use: Fix his car

loans.name: Abdel Majid

texts.en: Abdel Majid is a 51-year-old married man with three children, living in Al Sarafand, southern Lebanon. 21 years ago he started working as a fisherman, and after having several loans from Ameen, he started a small business to distribute fish in the South. Today, Abdel Majid is requesting $1,000 in order to increase his inventory.

loans.use: Increase Inventory

loans.name: Adeyi

texts.en: Adeyi S. is a 40-year-old married man with three children.  To earn a living, he sells palm kernels to both retail and wholesale customers.  He notes that he has a great deal of experience in this line of business.  Now, he is seeking a loan in the amount of $675 (100,000 NGN) to purchase more palm kernels for resale purposes.  He thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: To expand his inventory by purchasing more palm kernels

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 30-year-old married man with two children, living in Al Ghazieh, southern Lebanon. He started selling watches in a shop, and in 2004 he started his own business, and today Ali is distributing watches in the South. Today, he wants to borrow $1,200 to buy more watches for a very good price, in order to sell them and increase his profit.

loans.use: Buy watches

loans.name: Oyeleni

texts.en: Oyeleni A. is a 35-year-old married man with four children.  To earn a living, he mills and sells bags of rice, and he notes that he has been in this line of business for many years.  He is now requesting a loan in the amount of $675 (100,000 NGN) in order to purchase more bags of rice to mill and resell. He thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: To expand his business by purchasing additional bags of rice

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en: Sunday K. is a 40-year-old married man with three children.  He lives in Ogbomosho, in the Oyo state of Nigeria, where he crushes and sells palm kernels for a living.  He explains that there is a high demand for palm kernels, and that he is eager to meet the demands of his customers.  As such, he is seeking a loan in the amount of $675 (100,000 NGN) to purchase more palm kernels to resell.  He thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: To meet customer demand and to expand his business by purchasing additional palm kernels

loans.name: Rusu

texts.en: Rusu V. is 56 years old. He farms grain and vegetables but lately his business hasn't done well because the demand from his customers is high but he did not have enough working capital to increase the quantity of his products. Rusu would like a loan from MicroInvest to help him expand business so his supply of produce will fulfill the demand of his customers.

loans.use: To increase working capital for his farming business

loans.name: Sola

texts.en: Sola B. is a 35-year-old married man with three children.  He lives in Ogbomosho, in the Oyo state of Nigeria, where he sells tailoring materials such as sewing threads and sewing needles.  In addition, he makes lovely designs for his customers.  He also explains that he has been in this line of business for a long time.  Nevertheless, he is hoping to expand his business, so he is seeking a loan in the amount of $350 (50,000 NGN) to purchase more tailoring materials for resale purposes.  He thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: To expand his business by purchasing additional tailoring materials

loans.name: Ana

texts.es: Ana es una mujer muy amable y alegre, tiene 50 años y es natal de Madre de Dios, vive en un cuarto alquilado, donde tiene su tienda de bebidas. Cuando Ana dejo su querida Madre de Dios (ciudad natal), se dijo así misma que tenia que ser fuerte y poner todas sus ganas para salir adelante. Han pasado 20 años desde ese momento y ahora cuenta con una tienda de bebidas en la ciudad de Juliaca, tiene ya 16 años en ese negocio y le encanta atender a sus clientes, es muy alegre, por eso su clientela prefieren comprar en su tienda. Ella sabe, que su trabajo es muy sacrificado, sobre todo cuando tiene que amanecerse, para satisfacer la demanda de sus productos, quiere para el futuro abrir un negocio de abarrotes y hacer crecer su negocio actual y para ello pondrá todo de su parte y no decaerá en el afán por conseguirlo. Es el cuarto préstamo que Ana realiza en MFP, en sus anteriores créditos, no ha tenido problemas con los pagos, es la socia más alegre de su banco comunal y les transmite a todas esa alegría. Con el dinero obtenido, piensa poner otro negocio, esta vez abrirá una tienda de abarrotes, la inversión será de aproximadamente 4800 soles, está dispuesta a poner dinero de su ahorro personal con tal de alcanzar sus metas.
texts.en:
Ana is a very happy and kind woman. She is 50 years old and is from Madre de Dios. She lives in a rented room where she has her drinks store.

When Ana left her beloved hometown (Madre de Dios), she told herself she would have to be strong and use all of her will to succeed. It has been 20 years since this moment and now she has a store where she sells drinks in the city of Juliaca. She now has 16 years' experience in this business and she loves to serve her customers. She is very cheerful, and because of this, her clientele prefers to buy from her store. She knows that she has to make sacrifices for her work, above all when she has to get up at dawn to satisfy the demand for her products. In the future she would like to open a grocery store and grow her current business. She will give it her all and will not give up her hard work to achieve this goal.

This is the fourth loan that Ana has sought with MFP and in her previous loans, she has not had any problems with repayments. She is the most cheerful member of her community bank, and she transmits her joy to others. With the money obtained through this loan, she will open her grocery store. The investment will be approximately 4800 soles, and she is prepared to use her personal savings to be able to achieve this goal.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment for her grocery store

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria Olawole is a 40-year-old married woman with one child.  She lives in Ogbomosho, in the Oyo state of Nigeria, where she sells provisions such as candles, juice, body cream, and bathing soaps.  She further explains that she started this business 6 years ago.  Now, she is seeking a loan in the amount of $350 (50,000 NGN) in order to purchase more provisions for resale purposes.  She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To increase inventory by purchasing additional goods

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.es: Beatriz de 29 años, es una mujer muy preocupada por el bienestar y educación de sus 2 pequeños hijos, vive alquilada en la casa de su tía y quiere salir adelante mejorando su negocio. Acompañada de sus dos pequeños hijos, Beatriz realiza sus hermosos tejidos artesanales, ella se los vende a un acopiador, el cual  posteriormente los pone a la venta en el mercado Tupac Amaru (Mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca). A Beatriz le gusta mucho tejer, es por eso que siempre hace modelos novedosos, aunque no todo lo que teje es fácil, ya que siempre le es molesto tejer los Chullos (Prenda de vestir para la cabeza), que son los que más se venden a los turistas, tiene pensado para el futuro de su negocio, poner una tienda donde pueda vender ella misma su tejidos.
