To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase clothing for resale.

loans.name: Joyce's Group

texts.en:
Joyce N., a widow, is one of the executive members of Kewerimidde group, working as the payments’ controller. She is a strong, hard-working lady, managing all manly duties like fishing using her late husband’s 3 boats and it is a paying job except that these days the fish are not easy to come by.

Joyce is also a farmer with various food plantations for both home consumption and for sale; she also has 3 Fresian cows at home for milk and she has a ready market for that milk with her daughter, in S.6 vacation, managing the sales. Joyce's husband's passing left her to provide for 10 kids, and one of her greatest achievements is being able to educate her children with no one below the level of S.6. Joyce needs a loan to help with buying fishing nets and employing labor on her farm for fast and high quality yields.

loans.use: Buying fishing nets and employing labor on her farm.

loans.name: Mith

texts.en: P., 35, is married and has three children. All three of her chldren are teenagers and attend school. She has been selling fish in the local market for a long time. She earns an income of $3 per day. She sells her fish by relying on her husband's fishing and sometimes buying from her supplier. In addition to this, she does rice farming. P. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer to use for her rice crop and to buy more fish to sell. The loan will help her to increase her income to support her family's needs.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Secondary School, Fadugu Group

texts.en:
These prospective borrowers are teachers at an Agricultural Secondary School in Fadugu.  It was founded in 2003. Today, it has a total of 580 pupils (both female and male) with a staff of sixteen teachers. This Agricultural Secondary School is the only secondary school in the whole Kasonko Chiefdom. Once pupils graduate from the school (which is a Junior Secondary School – JSS), they then move to a senior secondary school in Kabala (twenty-five miles from Fadugu), which is the nearest  big town to Fadugu. Others go to other bigger towns like Makeni, Bo, Kenema, or Freetown. The school teaches mainly agriculture which is the primary occupation of the people of Fadugu. 

Since it is the only secondary school in the chiefdom, accommodating the pupils has become a problem for the school. The school lacks enough buildings to house the growing number of pupils within and around the whole chiefdom. Staffing too is another problem facing the school; almost all of the teachers in the school are unqualified. In addition to these problems, the library lacks the required textbooks.


Notwithstanding these constraints facing the school, this secondary school prides itself on producing 100% passes at the Basic Education Examination (BECE) for the academic years of 2005 – 2007. Though the school may lack trained and qualified teachers (since it is in a small town,; the few qualified and trained teachers in the country prefer teaching in bigger towns), it has determined, dedicated and willing teachers who are willing and ready to assist the children to make the grade. 

Patrick M. T. (left) is the Principal of the school. He has been in the teaching profession for thirty-one years.  He is fifty years of age, married with six children, all of whom are still in school. Patrick M. T. will use part of his share of the loan to buy building materials in order to start building his first house and part to pay his children’s school fees.

loans.use: to buy building materials and children's school fees

loans.name: Fatoumata Dite Awa

texts.fr:
Madame  Fatoumata Koné dite Awa est une veuve  de 48 ans qui vit chez  son feu mari avec  ses 7 enfants dans le quartier Bagadadji de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école  pour des raisons sociales, elle commença très tôt à mener une activité génératrice de revenu notamment la préparation et vente d’encens. En plus de l’encens elle aussi de l’habillement Elle a appris cette activité  de préparation d’encens auprès de sa tante qui avait une grande expertise dans cette activité. Son apprentissage n’a pris qu’un mois, elle l’a mène seule depuis 15 ans et jouit d’une grande réputation. Elle reçoit des commandes des grandes familles maraboutiques de  Ségou, de Bamako (capitale du Mali), et de l’extérieur (Sénégal, côte d’ivoire  et  la  France.
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle, elle a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est en relation  depuis trois ans. Après 3 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et 2 prêts individuels tous correctement  remboursés, elle est à son  3ème prêt individuel
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 1kg de magnonkisén, 20 bouteilles d’eau de Cologne, 2 pièces de bazins car  en sus  de cette transformation d’encens elle vend aussi des habits. Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières  sur place à ségou.
Madame Fatoumata Koné dite Awa vend généralement,  l’encens  au comptant  et les habits à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000 FCFA, qui lui permettra de supporter certaines charges familiales.
Elle ambitionne de faire l’embouche ovine et de se construire une maison.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata Koné a.k.a Awa is a 48-year-old widow. She lives with her 7 children in her deceased husband’s home in the neighborhood of Bagadadji in Ségou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

She abandoned her schooling early due to social reasons; early on she started an income-generating business, in particular, the preparation and sale of incense. In addition to the incense she also sells clothing. She learned the business of preparing incense from her aunt who was a great expert in this field. Her training only took one month; she has practiced her trade alone for the last 15 years and enjoys a great reputation. She receives orders from large marabou families from Segou, Bamako (the capital of Mali), and from outside the country (Senegal, Ivory Coast and France).

In order to meet her customers’ needs, she receives helps from the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which she has had a relation for the last 3 years. After 3 solidarity loans (group loans) and 2 individual loans, all fully paid back, she is requesting her third individual loan.

She wishes to use this loan to buy 1 kg of magnonkisèni [Highly valued exotic plant in West Africa], 20 bottles of eau de Cologne, and 2 pieces of bazin [fabric] because in addition to transforming incense she also sells clothing. She gets her supplies in raw material on the spot in Segou.

Mrs. Fatoumata Koné a.k.a Awa usually sells the incense for cash and the clothing on credit to customers who are men and women.

With this loan she hopes to make a profit of 40 000FCFA [about USD 77], which will allow her to provide for some of the family’s expenses.

Her ambition is to fatten sheep and to build herself a house.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw material to make incense and clothing.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 42-year-old Eva S. from Dar es Salaam. She is single with three children between the ages of 14 and 25. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent because his parents cannot take care of him. 

Eva has been running a poultry business since 2006. Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. 
First, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally! Second, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Third, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. 

She works at the business for 5-8 hours per day, seven days per week. Eva currently earns about US$500 from her business. She is requesting a loan to build a house for raising kuku. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Eva thanks you for your support!
	
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To build a house for her chickens.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: replenish her inventory

loans.name: Bharawan Allah Baksh Group

texts.en:
"My name is Bharawan and I’m a 28-year-old married lady and a citizen of a city called Multan, Pakistan for the past 10 years. Multan city is famous for its shrines and handmade items. I married a man whose name is A. B. and he runs a grocery shop with an experience of 10 years. I have three daughters. All of my daughters are getting an education from a school which is located near our house. I am a seamstress and take orders from my relatives and from my neighbors. I do this work to share the financial burden of my husband. I’ve successfully repaid my first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now I’m applying again for a loan to buy groceries for my husband’s grocery shop.

I am leading a few more ladies in my group. Manzooran baji and Naziran baji and Shahnaz baji each want a loan to buy buffalos for their milk-selling businesses. Ishrat baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for our grocery shop

loans.name: Abdurauf

texts.en:
Abdurauf S. is 20 years old. For about two years, Ehsonjon has been selling flowers. His sales point is located in the central flower market of the city and he works from the early morning till the late evening. Before this, he helped his mother with selling small things and then he decided to start his own business in order to help his mother with household expenses, since his father died 6 years ago. 

Over the years he has been working,  Ehsonjon became an expert in his business, knowing even how to keep the flowers safe during severe winter. The business is successful aand generating a stable income for his small family. Now he is requesting 800 USD for a term of 12 months. The loan will be spent to purchase flowers to sell. He thanks all for supporting him and promises to be precise in loan repayment. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing flowers to sell

loans.name: Elvania's Group

texts.en:
Elvania W. is a member of Kewerimidde lending group in Katosi. She is a strong married older lady. Elvania has a business selling petrol from a pump in Katosi and she has been able to educate her children; the last-born has just completed Makerere University. She mainly sells to taxi owners, trucks that collect sand as well as to personal vehicles, and the market is still good because she has a loyal customer base.

Elvania is also a farmer both for sale and home consumption as well as owning two cows that give her milk. She now works hard to ensure that her orphaned grandchildren attain the best of education. She needs another loan to help with filling her pump with petrol plus employing manpower on her farmlands for better yields.

loans.use: petrol to fill her pump plus manpower for her farm.

loans.name: Safiatou

texts.fr:
Madame    Safiatou  Djourté  est âgée de 39 ans, mariée elle vit  dans une famille monogamique avec  son mari et  ses 6 enfants dans le quartier Sébougou de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fait l’école, elle fréquenta la medersa et l’abandonna tôt. Elle s’initie au commerce auprès de sa maman qui vendait des habits. Rapidement  elle a compris les rouages du commerce. Après avoir mener plusieurs activités génératrices de revenu, elle opta pour le commerce de chaussures qu’elle  mène depuis 2 ans dans le quartier Secoura près de l’usine GDCM. Elle jouit d’une grande clientèle et d’une notoriété sans pareil car, elle est la seule vendeuse de chaussures dans cet environ. 
C’est dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour faire face à la demande de sa clientèle qu’elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, elle est en relation  depuis 42 mois. Après avoir  3 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et 2 prêts  individuels tous  bien remboursés, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser  ce prêt pour acheter 100 paires de chaussures, sur place au grand marché de Ségou auprès des grossistes.
Madame  Safiatou  Djourté  vend  en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 75 000 FCFA, qui lui permettra d’acheter une charrette et un réfrigérateur. Son ambition est d’avoir une compagnie de transport public (Djourté trans.)
texts.en:
Ms. Safiatou Djourté, age 39, is married and lives in a monogamous family with her husband and six children in the Sébougou district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having gone to school, she attended the medersa and soon abandoned it. She got introduced to commerce by her mom, who used to sell clothing. She quickly understood all the ins and outs of the business. After having done many kinds of income-generating work, she opted for commerce in shoes, which she has been doing for two years in the Secoura district, near the GDCM factory. She enjoys a large customer base and unparalleled distinction because she is the only retailer of shoes in this area.

With plans to increase her working capital for coping with customer demands, she is turning to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, which she has been associated with for 42 months. After having received three solidarity loans (group loans) and two individual loans, all repaid, she is now on her third individual loan. She plans to use this loan to buy 100 pairs of shoes, locally from wholesalers at the grand marketplace of Ségou. Sales are made at the retail level, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed of men and women.

She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA that will enable her to buy a chart and a refrigerator. Her ambition is to have a public transport company (Djourté Trans.)

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shoes

loans.name: Batzul

texts.en: Batzul G. is an energetic, single, young man who runs a vegetable sales business. He lives in a "ger",  the traditional nomadic Mongolian house, at the ger district in the Mongolian capital, Ulaanbaatar. His home is situated on land owned by his brother. Since 2000, Batzul has bought a large amount of vegetables including carrots, potatoes, lettuce, beets and onions from the biggest vegetable market, "Bars", located in Ulaanbaatar. He then sells them in a local district market. He wants to invest heavily in his stock for the lunar new year. His monthly income from sales is MNT 2,400,000 to 2,600,000 (about $1,650 USD). This business gives him 20-50% profit on capital. Batzul also plants potatoes and carrots on his own land, which is located out of town.

loans.use: to buy more volume of vegetables during the luner new year period.

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 33-year-old Nuru L. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children, ages 10 and 13. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because they are orphans. Nuru has been running a grocery business since 2008. She works at the business 13-16 hours per day, seven days per week. Nuru currently earns about US$300 from her business. She is requesting a loan to purchase grocery items. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. Nuru thanks you for your support!
	
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items.

loans.name: Razia M. Ramzan Group

texts.en:
Razia Baji is a 36-year-old married lady and has resided in a city named Multan, Pakistan for the past 25 years. 'My husband's name is M. R., an animal seller for the past 10 years. He buys animals from the famous animal market of Multan and sells them to the different butcher shops.' Razia Baji has three kids: one son and two daughters. All of her kids are getting an education from the school which located near their house. Razia Baji shares the financial burden of her husband by doing embroidery on dresses. She gets orders from her neighbors and charges $3 for per embroidered dress. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy more livestock (goats and sheep) to sell.

She is a group leader of some more women of her locality. Mubarak Baji and Manzooran Mai Baji and Shamim Baji each want a loan to buy buffalo for their milk selling businesses. Zafran Baji wants a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animals to sell

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita A. is a seaweed grower. She also owns a store where she sells a variety of goods. She is 47 years old and has 8 children. Her husband, Ramon A., helps her raise their children. She previously worked as a checker in a furniture company. She was not happy about her previous job because of its low salary, so she decided to start a seaweed farming business. She dreams of having a bigger store someday. In this way, she will be able to send all her children to school. 

She is asking for a CEVI loan of Php 17,000 ($375 USD). Her loan will be used to buy seaweed seedlings. This will help her increase the size of her farm. 

CEVI is helping seaweed farmers like Juanita to grow their businesses. They are provided with credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to sustain their businesses.

loans.use: To buy seaweed seedlings and merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Tantou

texts.fr:
Madame  Tantou  Sow  est âgée de 40 ans, mariée elle vit avec son mari et ses 6 enfants  dans une grande  famille avec d’autres ménages, dans le quartier Missira de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école  en classe de 9ème (niveau collège)  pour se marier, elle commence à mener plusieurs activités génératrices de revenu auprès de sa mère qui faisait le petit commerce d’articles divers. Depuis maintenant 7 ans, elle a décidé de rester dans ce créneau de commerce d’articles divers telles que la vente de bois de chauffe, de jus et de glace, de chaussures, d’habits, d’huiles alimentaires,  etc. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation et d’une grande clientèle. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter son fonds de commerce elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance avec qui elle est à son premier prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 30 pièces de pagnes Wax, 20 paires de chaussures et 20litres d’huile de palme.
Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières à Bamako(capitale du Mali) ou au Burkina Faso.
Madame Tantou  Sow  vend de façon ambulante et fixe en détail au comptant et à crédit (payable mensuellement pour les habits et hebdomadairement pour l’huile de palme et les chaussures) à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 25 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour la prise en charge des dépenses familiales. Son ambition est d’ouvrir une boutique d’habits et de chaussures.
texts.en:
Mrs. Tantou S.is 40 years old, married and lives her husband and 6 children in a large family (including other family members) in the Missira neighborhood of Segou ( fourth administrative region in the Republic of Mali ) She left school in the ninth grade to marry and started to earn income through several business activities. Her mother, who had a business selling a variety of articles, taught her the trade. After 7 years, she has decided to remain in the business of selling miscellaneous items, such as fire wood, juice, ice, shoes, clothing, basic oils, etc. She enjoys a great reputation and a large clientele. In an effort to increase her operating capital, she joined the microfinance institute and made her first individual loan. She expects to use this loan to buy 30 pieces of Wax pagne (decorative cloth), 20 pairs of shoes, and 20 liters of palm oil. She buys from first class wholesalers in Bamako ( capital of Mali ) or at Burkina Faso. Mrs Tantou S.goes door to door selling retail for cash or credit (payable monthly for cloths and weekly for palm oil and shoes). Her clientele is made up of both men and women. She expects to make a monthly profit of 25,000 FCFA which will be used to meet family expenses. Her ambition is to open a clothing and shoes boutique.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 30 pieces of Wax pagne (decorative cloth), 20 pairs of shoes, and 20 liters of palm oil

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary B. sells soft drinks and clothing at the council lane in Elmina. Mary has received a junior high education.  She is married and has 1 child.  Her husband is a steel bender. Mary started selling soft drinks and clothing not too long ago. She is responsible for the housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family's financial needs. Her loan will be used to buy more bales of clothing and crates of soft drinks to meet the increase in demand by her custumers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back for the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: Buy more bales of clothing and crates of soft drinks to meet the increase in demand by her custumers.

loans.name: Mat

texts.en: E. is 58 years old and is a resident of Pursat Province where she has owned a plot of land since 1979. She grows rice crops, which she plants twice a year during the dry season and rainy season. She is widowed and is the mother of three children. All of her children are single. To help the family, three of her children are employed. One of her employed daughters is running a small grocery store. To earn additional income, E. is requesting a loan for her daughter so she can buy more grocery inventory for sale.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma C., a 29-year-old mother, sells dried fish for a living. She never minds the labor and the smell of the fish she sells. She is doing her best to earn money to support her 3 children. Her business is a big help and has sustained the family. She has used her profits to pay school tuition for her children, cover their daily expenses, and buy their food. 

She started her business in 2006 with Php 10,000 ($250 USD). Her business has grown, so she needs more capital to accommodate more customers. She is asking for a loan of Php 5,000 ($125 USD) to buy more fish to sell. In this way, she believes, she will have more profit for her family.

CEVI helps fish vendors like Thelma grow their businesses. They are provided with credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to sustain their businesses.

loans.use: To buy additional dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Sulton

texts.ru:
Cултон мужчина 38 лет , отец троих детей , жена продавец в магазине.Сам Султон работает на заводе по ремонту автомобилей.Он мастер по ремонту моторов легковых авто. Помимо своей работы он имеет также дополнительный бизнес, производство и продажа пчелиного мёда.У него очень вкусный и целебный мёд,который пользуется большим спросом на рынке Худжанда.Для закупа оптом сахара ему понадобился кредит.
Для чего он и обратился в Микроинвест.
texts.en:
Sulton, 38, married, is a father of three. His wife works as a salesperson at a retail store. Sulton works as a mechanic at an auto repair factory. Sulton specializes in repairing engines of passenger vehicles. In addition to his job at the factory, Sulton keeps honeybees. His bees produce delicious and salubrious honey, which is in great demand at the Khudzhand market. Sulton will use this loan for wholesale purchase of sugar for his bees.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sugar for honeybees

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience S. is married and has 1 child. She has received schooling through junior high. Patience sells used clothing at Elmina, which she started not too long ago. Her husband is a commercial driver. Patience uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family's financial needs.

Patience will use the loan as additional capital to enable her increase the sale of used clothing to meet the increase in demand by her custumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Patience plans to develop a plot of land which she bought with her husband to put up their family house.

loans.use: Increase the sale of used clothing to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Saliyu

texts.en: Saliyu J. is 45 years old and married with 4 children. Saliyu sells drinks (dry gin) at wholesale and retail. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She hopes to expand her business and increase her profits. She is indeed grateful to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks (dry gin) to sell

loans.name: Cheat

texts.en: L., age 28, raises pigs in a stall next to her house. She will sell her pigs to a slaughterer six months after they mature. She is married to Teng, who is 26 years old, and who works as a carrying worker at the busy market. The young couple is responsible for two young children. L. is requesting a loan to buy a piglet to raise and to build a small store to begin working as a grocery seller.

loans.use: To buy piglet to raise and to build a small grocery store

loans.name: Ma. Nenita

texts.en:
Ma. Nenita A. sells fish. She is 50 years old and has 10 children. When she was just a child, her parents, also  fish vendors, always took her to sell fresh fish in the market. She dreams that all her children will graduate from college and continuously chase their dreams.

In 1979, she started selling fish and has been able to grow her business. Her profits go to pay the family's daily expenses, as well as for school fees and other projects. She is asking CEVI for a loan of Php 18,000 ($400 USD). She will use the loan to buy a pump boat. Once she has the boat, it will be easy for her to catch more fish to sell.

CEVI gives their clients like A. credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to help them grow their businesses.

loans.use: To buy a pump boat for her fish business.

loans.name: Bahrom

texts.ru: Бахром молодой человек 30 лет , женат имеет одного ребёнка,крутой бизнесмен.Сам привозит товар и реализует его на рынке Худжанда.В его ассортимент входят продукты питания такие как сахар,сладкие изделия , соль печенье и.т.д.Его жена занимается продажей женской одежды на вещевом рынке.Бахром для увеличения товарооборота хочет взять кредит.
texts.en:
Bahrom, 30, is married and has one child. Bahrom is a successful businessman. He produces many of the products he sells at the Khudzhand market including sweets, cookies, etc. His wife sells clothing for women. Bahrom will use this loan to increase the assortment of goods sold.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the assortment of goods sold

loans.name: Godfrey's Group

texts.en:
M. Godfrey is the chairperson of Kigalama development group in Mityana. He is 45 years of age and married with 6 children, of whom four are in school. He is a farmer with plantations of banana, maize, beans, rice and plantains and he is happy that they are giving him high quality yields due to the care he gives them. He employs men and women to help him on his farm along with his wife and children and as a result, he has food to feed his home as well as for sale.

This is the rainy season everywhere in Uganda and Godfrey is spending most of his time in the farm, overseeing all that is going on. He needs a loan to help with buying seedlings for his plantains as well as employing labor for his various plantations.

loans.use: Buying seedlings for his plantains as well as employing labor on his various plantations.

loans.name: Juliet C.'s Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the District Education Committee Primary School, Fadugu (D.E.C). It was built by the government in 1950. It has a total of twenty-one staff and 535 pupils. D.E.C is one of the three primary schools in Fadugu (a small town about twenty-five miles from Kabala).

D.E.C is the most popular primary school in Fadugu. The school always gets a 100% passes at the National Primary School Exams (BECE). It is also victorious in quiz and cultural competitions organized by N.G.Os like Cause Canada and CADO. In sport, they also always triumph over the other two primary schools in the town.

As part of their constraints, D.C.E lacks sufficient latrines for the 535 pupils it has – they only have six pit holes. D.C.E. also lacks a good water well to serve the children of this school. The only water well they have dries up completely during the dry season. Accommodation is also another problem for the children of D.E.C. The building is too small to accommodate the 535 pupils. Staff of D.E.C are working hard to meet these challenges; they are currently seeking assistance from the various N.G.Os in Koinadugu district. Fortunately, they are very grateful to VDC (Village Development Partnership, an NGO of former American Peace Corps), who are currently constructing them a three class-room building, the first to benefit from VDC in the Koinadugu district.

Juliet C. Conteh (2nd from right) is the Deputy Head Teacher of the school. Juliet is married to a soldier and the two of them have four children together. One of their children is in college, and the others are in Senior Secondary School (SSS) I, II and III. Juliet will divide her loan into three partitions: 1) to buy building materials 2) to pay school fees for her children and 3) to invest in business.

loans.use: Buy building materials, pay school fees and invest in business

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce A. sells used clothing at Bantama near Elmina. Joyce has received a junior high education. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a translator at the Elmina court. Joyce started selling used clothing not too long ago. She has no financial responsibilities since her husband takes care of all the financial expenses of the family. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her increase the sale of used clothing to meet the increase in demand by her custumers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards the expansion of the her trade.

loans.use: Increase the sale of used clothing to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Gulzar Allah Wasaya Group

texts.en:
Gulzar Baji is a 37-year-old married lady and has resided in a city named Multan, Pakistan for the past 24 years. Her husband's name is A. W. and he has had a dairy business for the past 10 years. He sells milk in the milk shops and in the community as well. Gulzar Baji helps him by milking the buffalo. Presently he has one buffalo at home. Gulzar Baji has three kids: one son and two daughters. All of her kids are getting an education from a school which located near their house. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo to expand her milk selling business.

She is a group leader of some more women of her locality. Zainab Mai and Manzooran Baji each want a loan to buy buffaloes for their milk selling businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for milk selling business

loans.name: Ibiwumi

texts.en: Ibiwumi is 32 years old and she is married with 2 children. She sells shoes. She hopes to expand her business and increase her profits. She needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more shoes to sell. She says thanks to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en: Iyabo A. sells clothes. She has been in this for a long time. The demands for her clothes are high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. Iyabo is 40 years old and married with 2 children. She is indeed grateful to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Mansab Mai Imtiaz Hussain Group

texts.en:
Mansab mai baji is a 31year old married lady and a citizen in a city called Multan, Pakistan, for the past 10 years. Her husband, I. H. is a farmer. Mansab baji helps him by sowing seeds in the field for the different crops that they grow. They both have been doing this work for 15 years. Mansab baji has one daughter who is in the 6th grade. 

Mansab baji has successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm. 

She is the leader of a loan group consisting of herself and another lady. Mumtaz baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee each others loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Ahror

texts.ru: Ахрор энергичный молодой человек, который занимается продажей видеокассет и дисков.Ахрор уже пятый он занимается этим бизнесом , у него свои постоянные клиенты.У нас население очень заинтересовано в просмотрах различных новых сериалов и музыкальных клипов,и эта продукция пользуется большим спросом.Ахрор в начале своей кредитной истории имел маленький оборот,на сегодняшний день он у него увеличился в двое.Теперь получив очередной займ Ахрор хочет купить хороший телевизор для предоставления просмотра дисков перед покупкой клиентам.
texts.en:
Ahror is an energetic young man. For five years now, Ahror has been selling video cassettes and DVDs. He has numerous loyal customers. The local population likes watching new movies, soaps, and music clips, so Ahror's goods are in great demand. Since taking his first loan, Ahror doubled the size of his business. Ahror wants to use this loan to purchase a quality TV, so that his customers can preview the videos, before buying them.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase video store inventory (TV)

loans.name: Romoke

texts.en: Romoke sells foodstuffs like dried yam and plantain. She hopes to expand her business. She requested a loan in the amount of N100000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. Romoke is 40 years old and she is married with 2 children. She lives in Ogbomosho, Oyo state, Nigeria. She says thanks to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies of food to sell

loans.name: Osim

texts.ru: Осим мужчина 39 лет имеет троих детей, жена работает учительницей в лицее гимназии.Сам Осим занимается бизнесом мужской обуви , которую привозит с Бишкека.Его товары очень качественные и пользуются большим спросом.Раньше Осим работал частным таксистом на своей собственной машине.Но его друг посоветовал ему начать свой бизнес, который даст ему больше дохода и его семейное положение улучшится.Послушав друга Осим начал ездить с ним за товаром.Постепенно войдя в калию Осим стал самостоятельно привозить товар.И теперь для увеличения ассортимента Осим хочет получить кредит.
texts.en:
Osim is a 39-year old father of three children. His wife is a teacher at a lyceum. Osim worked as a private taxi driver with his own vehicle. But his friend, a shuttle trader, suggested that Osim starts his own business, which would bring more profit. Osim first joined his friend but later started travelling to Bishkek independently. He sells high quality men's shoes, and his products are in high demand. Now Osim is applying for a loan that would allow him expand his business.

Translated from Russian by Oksana Buranbaeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: shoes

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah B. is married and has 3 children. She has received schooling through junior high. Hannah sells clothing and fabric. She is a seamstress who has specialized in sewing lady's ware at Bantama, near Elmina. She recently started this business. Her husband is a carpenter. Hannah uses her income to support her husband in paying rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Hannah will use the loan to purchase a greater quantity and variety of  fabrics and other sewing materials for her sewing work. With the new profits from her expanded business, Hannah plans to save towards a house that she wants to put up with her husband for their children.

loans.use: To purchase a greater quantity and variety of  fabrics and other sewing materials for her sewing business

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort has a restaurant where she sells cooked foods and drinks. She started this business in 1998. She needs the loan amount of N50, 000 to purchase more drinks and food supplies to cook and sell to her customers. She is 54 years old and married with 6 children. She says thanks to all kiva lenders and LAPO microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and food supplies to cook and sell

loans.name: Miron

texts.en:
Miron is married with two grown children. His family lives in Stryi, where Miron runs his small business, offering leasing services to individuals and legal entities. Miron has wide experience; working as an engineer, head of a small store and owner of furniture manufacturing business. He decided to use all his previous experience to launch a new venture and started this estate leasing business a year ago.   

Miron is hoping to use the loan of 7,500 Grivnas to finish remodeling several facilities for leasing purposes. Miron purchased these premises and owns them. His good reputation in the community has helped him build trust with his clientele. Miron is not only a man of integrity but also a man of compassion. He takes care of his disabled neighbor helping him with groceries, house cleaning and other basic needs.

loans.use: To finish remodeling in several rooms

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy some vegetables for resale

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en: Augustina M. sells groceries like biscuits, canned products and other items at Domamudo, near Elmina. Augustina has received junior high education.  She is married and has 2 children. Her husband is a carpenter. Augustina started selling groceries like biscuits, canned products and other items not too long ago. She has no financial responsibilities since her husband takes care of all the financial expenses of the family. Her loan will be used to buy more groceries to meet the increase in demand from her costumers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards the expansion of the her trade.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Ganna

texts.en:
Ganna is married with a son. She is from Stryi, Western Ukraine. Ganna owns a business selling men’s clothing in the local market. She has a serious business approach focusing on client demand and modern fashion trends. Ganna has been in this trade for 5 years. Presently, she has about 10,000 Grivnas in inventory. 

Ganna is very enthusiastic about her venture and business as such. You can definitely call Ganna a workaholic. She invests all her energy in her business and seeks to see its growth. One of her dreams is to buy a small store and move her business there. Ganna is requesting a loan of 3,000 Grivnas to purchase additional merchandise, e.g. men’s sweaters and shorts, and boost her sales this spring season.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth A. is 45 years old and married with 3 children. She sells foodstuffs like rice, bean, tubers of yams and cassava. She is a LAPO client. She needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is indeed grateful to Kiva lenders and LAPO microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Bose

texts.en: Bose A. is a LAPO client. She lives in Ogbomosho, Oyo state, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs like beans, rice, etc. She hopes to expand her business. She needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is 38 years old and married with 4 children. She says thanks to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine M. is a single parent and has 1 child. She has received schooling through junior high. Josephine sells phone snap cards and also prepares food for sale at Akotobinsin near Elmina, which she started not too long ago. Josephine uses her income to pay for the child's school fees, rent, utility bills and other financial expenses . Josephine will use the loan to increase her capital to buy more phone credit cards and also ingredients for the food preparation in larger quantities for sale to her ever increasing costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Josephine plans to reinvest back for the expansion of  her trade.

loans.use: Josephine will use the loan to increase her capital to buy more phone credit cards and also ingredients for the food preparation in larger quantities for sale to her ever increasing costumers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy generic pharmaceuticals and also to rent a store

loans.name: Obéissance Group

texts.en: José has been selling round flat biscuits since 2003. He sold his shirt for $2.50 to start his business. He used that money to buy several kilos of wheat flour, some sugar, baking powder and some charcoal to start making round flat biscuits.  From 2003 to 2006, José’s business was prosperous and he used the profits generated to increase his working capital $41. From 2006 to 2008, he diversified his business by adding doughnuts and packaging materials. He joined one of Hope’s groups called “Obéissance,” meaning “Obedience,” in October 2008. The loans received from Hope have strengthened his business. He is planning with the next loan to diversify his business and increase profit by adding purified water. Currently, his working capital is about $200. José’s business makes about $6 of profit per day. He is ambitious and dreams someday to open a small store. José is 43 years old, married, and has five children between the ages 2 and 10. Three of them are pupils. He also takes care of his younger brother who is still a student. José likes his business because it has stabilized him financially. His community bank group consists of 41 members.

loans.use: To diversify his business by adding purified water

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Adio

texts.en: Adio K. sells blocks. He is 42 years old and married with 4 children. He hopes to expand this business. He needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more blocks to sell. He says thanks to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more blocks to sell

loans.name: Afusat

texts.en: Afusat I. is 29 years old and single. She sells clothes, bags and shoes. She started this business in 2005. She hopes to expand her business. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more clothes, bags and shoes to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, bags and shoes to sell

loans.name: Rc Primary School, Fadugu Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the St. Peters and Paul RC Fadugu.  It was built by Nancy B. K. in 1981 to promote education in the Chiefdom of Kasonko. It has a total of ten staff and 400 pupils. St. Peters and Paul RC Fadugu is one of the three primary schools in Fadugu, a small town about twenty-five miles from Kabala.

St. Peters and Paul RC Fadugu makes good grades at the National Primary School Examination (BECE) every academic year. The school has been able to send many pupils to secondary schools in bigger towns.

Until Sabobu Education completes constructing them a new school building, they are in short of sufficient class rooms to house the 400 pupil they have. Water well is also another problem facing this school.

Nancy B. K. (3rd from right) is the Deputy Head Teacher of this school and the founder of the school. She was born in Kamabai (about twenty-five mile from Fadugu) fifty-eight years ago. She is a widow with five children between the ages of eighteen and thirty-two. Nancy will be using her loan to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Will use the loan to pay school fees

loans.name: Oluwabunmi

texts.en: Oluwabumi is 29 years old and she is single. She is a tailor and she makes lovely designs for her customers. She also sells tailoring materials like needles, sewing thread, etc. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy the ingredients necessary for making foufou

loans.name: Tajudeen's Group

texts.en: Tajudeen crushes palm kernel. He has been in this business for a long time. He purchases the palm kernel and crushes it to sell to his customers. He needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more palm kernel to sell. He is 38 years old and married with a child. His wife is a tailor. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more palm kernel to crush

loans.name: Adigun

texts.en: Adigun D. lives in Ogbomosho, Oyo State, Nigeria. Adigun is 43 years old and married with 4 children. Adigun crushes palm kernel. He has been in this business for a long time. He purchases the palm kernel and crushes it to sell to his customers. He hopes to expand his business and increase his profits. He needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more palm kernel to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more palm kernel to crush and sell.

loans.name: Edward's Group

texts.en: W. Edward is a member of Kigalama group in Mityana. He is a hard working and devoted man with a bar as his business. He sells all sorts of beers and spirits including local brew for his customers in Kigalama T.C. He has been in this business for 8 years and is grateful that he is and has always been able to operate his bar with the help of loans. In addition, he is also a farmer with gardens that he usually manages in the morning hours while the bar mainly booms in the evenings and afternoons. He has been able to buy himself a plot of land out of his accumulated savings and this time round, he seeks a loan to help with buying beers, sodas, wines and local brew for his bar.

loans.use: Buying more beers, sodas, wines and local brew for his bar.

loans.name: Fatima Ejaz M.irfan Group

texts.en:
Fatima E. baji is a 46 year-old widow and has resided in a city named Multan, Pakistan for the past 35 years.  Fatima baji is a graduate passed lady. Her education supports her when she faced crucial circumstances after the death of her husband. Fatima baji became the only breadwinner of her family. She is the mother of four kids: three daughters and one son. Her elder daughter works in a government office. Fatima baji didn’t stop her children’s education even knowing that how difficult it is. She never loses hope; she started a boutique from the committee amount. She got good recognition gradually in the community. Now her elder daughter also helps her in making dresses for the boutique.  She has successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy material (cloth, colored thread) to make more dresses to display in boutique. 

She is a group leader of some more women of her locality. Zaitoon begum baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Zahida mai baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Syeda bano baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Yasmeen baji wants a loan to buy cotton to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for boutique

loans.name: Rusu

texts.en: N. is 63 years old and lives in the Cimislia district. Every day he wakes up early and is eager to work hard and make his land fruitful for growing grain and vegetables but he does not have enough working capital to do this. N. would like a loan from MicroInvest to buy seeds, fuel, and equipment, such as a plow, shovels, and so on. He is confident that he will be able to repay the money in 2 months, after the 11-month grace period, because he always has a rich harvest.

loans.use: To purchase more seeds and farm equipment

loans.name: Zahida M. Arshad Group

texts.en:
Zahida baji is a 30 year-old old married lady and a citizen of a city named Multan, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband's name is M. A. and he runs a boutique where he displays his collection which he prepared with the help of his wife Zahida baji. Zahida baji is the mother of one son who has a chicken-meat selling business for the past 2 years. Zahida baji is applying for a loan to buy material (colored thread, cloth and beads) to expand her husband’s boutique. 

She is a group leader of some more women from her locality. Asia baji wants a loan to buy cotton to sell. Abida baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Sajida baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for boutique

loans.name: Mujeres Exitosas Group

texts.en:
“Mujeres Exitosas”, or Successful Women, is a group of 10 women entrepreneurs seeking their second loan from Esperanza International.  The group’s past loan has been successfully repaid, and the group hopes to utilize a second loan for further business expansion.  Isela is one of the coordinators of the group in Santiago.  

Isela, mother of three (ages: 25, 26, 27) is expecting her first grandchild and is thrilled to share this fact with whomever she comes into contact with.  Isela, aided by her first microfinance loan with Esperanza International, opened Dominican snack sales of “quipes” and “pastelitos”, both consisting of a fried dough with a meat, vegetable or cheese filling. Isela plans to use her second microfinance loan to purchase additional materials needed to make her snacks and dreams of one day being able to own her own store from which she may sell these fried snacks.    

Other member’s of Isela’s microfinance bank run similar entrepreneurial operations including undergarment, vegetable and ice-cream sales.    

On behalf of Esperanza and this group of business entrepreneurs, we would like to thank you for your support!

loans.use: Purchase materials needed to produce fried snacks

loans.name: Khatoon M.azam Group

texts.en:
Khatoon baji is a 40 year-old married lady and has resided in a city named Multan, Pakistan for the past 30 years. Her husband's name is M. and he sells embroider items (beads and colored thread) in the markets. People used to come to him for buying these items. Khatoon baji is the mother of five kids: three sons and two daughters. Her first two sons help their father in embroider items selling business. Her younger son reads in kindergarten. Her elder daughter reads in 4th standard and her younger daughter reads in 3rd standard. Khatoon baji is a seamstress; she sews clothes by taking orders from her neighbors and relatives. She does this work to pay off the school fees of her children. She is applying for a loan to buy material (beads and colored thread) to expand her husband’s embroider items selling business. 

She is a group leader of some more women of her locality. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to sell. Yasmeen baji and Fozia baji each want a loan to buy donkey carts for loading. Bushra balooch baji wants a loan to buy items (cloth, colored thread and sketches) for her embroider business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy embroider material to sell

loans.name: Johnbosco's Group

texts.en:
E. Lubega is married with 6 kids. He cares for his other 3 kids and pays school fees for all his children except one who is not in school. His eldest child is in secondary school. E. has a retail shop, which he has been running for 2 years, as well as a farming business that produces coffee, which has been running for considerably longer. All his businesses are in a local trading center. He also has had a solar power business for 8 months for charging mobile phones since his neighborhood has no electricity. In a week he makes a profit of 5000 ugsh. 

He says he has been successful in his business because he has no competition and he treats his customers well. Getting a loan has helped him because it has enabled him to pay for the capital requirements of his business. His business dream is to open another retail shop in a much bigger town.

He has requested a loan amount of 1,000,000 ugsh. His plan is to restock his retail shop. He also plans to buy a refrigerator so he can start selling cold drinks. This is his 6th loan from PEARL. (In the photo are 23 people of which 3 are staff from Pearl Microfinance).

loans.use: Restock his retail shop, farm labor

loans.name: Crucian

texts.en: E. Crucian is 44 years old and has been a farmer in the Cimislia district for more than 12 years. E. launched her business in 1998 and it has been successful but now she is struggling because she can't afford to buy the equipment she needs to expand her business. She would like a loan from MicroInvest to obtain these materials. E. is glad that Microinvest is willing to give loans to such customers who have a desire to work hard but do not have the working capital.

loans.use: To buy farm materials and equipment

loans.name: Mukisa Group

texts.en:
N. A. is a soft-spoken mother of 8 children. She is also a caretaker of three other family members. Of the 8 children, 4 are adults, and 2 have attained university level education. She has a food business which produces mainly Matoke, which is a local staple. The main challenge in her business is the fluctuating prices of the goods. At time of buying, prices can vary widely.

She earns about 70000 ugsh /week in profit. She's been in business for about 15 years and has been involved with her lending group for 11. The strength of her business, she says, is having great customer care. 

Her benefits from the loan include her ability to build her own house and send all her kids to school. She started borrowing 50,000 Ugsh 15 years ago. Now she has gone up to 900,000. This is her 36th loan. She is so grateful that the loans have enabled her to send her kids to school. 

Her vision is to have all her children attend University.

loans.use: Buying goods for her food shop

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda H., 34 years old, is a seaweed grower. Every day, she goes out on the sea to plant seaweed, feeling the heat of the sun to provide what her family needs. Her husband, Julito H., helps her plant seaweed to support their family. She previously worked as an encoder. But when she decided to get married, she left that job and started a seaweed farming business instead. She and her husband started their seaweed business using their own money; they grow the business by reinvesting their income. The business is located in Hingotanan, a very popular island in Bohol. Brenda is asking for a CEVI loan of Php 10,000 ($225 USD) to buy more seaweed for the farm. She believes that her loan will bring her a bigger harvest and more income for the family.
CEVI helps Brenda sustain her seaweed farm. Now, she enjoys the credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage that CEVI gives to all their clients.

loans.use: To expand her seaweed farming business.

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia P. is a seaweed grower. With her previous loan from CEVI, she bought seedlings and started to plant. The profit she gets from planting seaweed is what she uses to feed her 5 children. Her husband is a fisherman. Whenever her husband catches plenty of fish, they sell fish in their neighborhood.

Her seaweed farm is on Hingotanan Island. Letecia thinks that her farm could help her support the needs of her children, especially the school fees and their other projects.

She is asking for a CEVI loan of Php 10,000 ($225 USD) to buy more seedlings for her seaweed farm. She believes that the more she plants, the greater harvest she will have. The loan will also be used to help her get started in another line of business.  

CEVI supports Letecia in her seaweed farm. Now, she enjoys credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage that CEVI gives to all its clients.

loans.use: To buy more seedlings for her seaweed farm

loans.name: Criselda

texts.en:
Criselda B. sells a variety of goods in her neighborhood. She realizes that she needs to work hard for her children. She is 55 and has two children who are studying.  CEVI helped her start her store in 2003. With Php 5,000 ($110 USD) capital, she managed to grow her business despite the competition. She uses the profit from her store to cover daily expenses, especially food and school fees for her children.

She is asking for a loan of Php 25,000 ($550 USD) from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy more rice and other merchandise for her store. Through this loan, she has an opportunity to increase her sales and income. Her loan will surely bring Criselda more profit in her business.

CEVI helps Criselda grow her business. She has access to credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage by joining the CEVI credit program.

loans.use: To buy more rice and other merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Timoteo

texts.en:
Timoteo T. buys coconut shells and charcoal and sells them to his clients. He is 37 years old and has 5 children. His wife, Lucina T., helps him run his business. He also sells gasoline by the roadside in San Miguel. The amount he earns from his extra business line truly helps in meeting the family's needs.

He is requesting a loan of 6,000 Php ($150 USD) from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy more coconuts and charcoal. In this way, he believes, he will earn more income from his business. He is also looking for some other line of business that could boost his income. 

CEVI supports Timoteo in his business. Now, he has credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage from CEVI. .

loans.use: To buy charcoal and coconut shells to sell

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.en:
Vicenta P. is 53 years old and owns a store. She sells a variety of goods in her neighborhood. In 1990, she started her business with capital of only 7,000 Php ($150 USD). Her store is growing and established. 

She is asking for a loan of Php 7,000 ($150 USD) from CEVI. She will use her loan to buy additional merchandise for her store. Part of the loan will be used to buy feed for her pigs. This loan will truly help Vicenta expand her business.

CEVI helps its clients sustain their businesses. Like Vicenta, more and more CEVI clients use its credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell in her store.

loans.name: Matei

texts.en: L. Matei is a very popular person in her village. She gives farming advice to the villagers about the best time for sowing seeds and when to harvest. In sharing her knowledge, L. has mentored some strong competitors on the local wholesale market in the Cimislia district. Using her vast experience, she would like to expand her own farming business. With a loan from MicroInvest, she will be able to offer a greater supply than her competitors.

loans.use: To increase her farm production and sales

loans.name: Fatuma's Group

texts.en: N. Fatuma is one of the executive members of Balyejusa group in Lugazi. She is a business woman with a tailoring business where she makes dresses, skirts, blouses as well as mending those that are already made. She has been getting loans for 4 years now and she is amazed by the change that has happened to her business. As a result of being able to make some weekly income of 80000 Ugshs, she has been able to buy another sewing machine totaling to two now, she has bought a bicycle that helps to fetch grass for her cow as well as owning more household items. She is married with 3 children, and also caring for 2 relatives with full responsibility for their welfare. She needs a loan to be able to buy more clothing materials for her tailoring business.

loans.use: Buying more clothing materials for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marilyn B. has a food vending business. She is 34 years old and has four children. Her husband, Jose Noel B., is very supportive of her in her business. They work together to support the needs of their children.

Her business is located near the school. This gives Marilyn her regular customers and income. She uses her profit  from selling food to cover her family's daily expenses.

She is asking for a CEVI loan of Php 8,000 ($175 USD). She will use the loan to buy food ingredients, and other items her business needs, to augment her income. She is also looking for some other possible income areas. In this way, she will have more sources of income for the family.

CEVI provides their clients credit assistance as well as training and insurance coverage to help their businesses grow.

loans.use: To buy additional ingredients for her food stand.

loans.name: Confianza Y Dignidad 2 Y 4 Group

texts.en: Marcia M. is the Group Coordinator for the Confianza y Dignidad (Trust and Dignity) Bank of Hope in Hato Mayor. This group of 5 hopes to utilize this microfinance loan to further establish their existing business ventures or create new operations in order to increase their profit levels. Marcia has 2 teenage children, ages 18 and 14. Marcia plans to utilize this loan to increase the inventory of the products she sells. Currently Marcia sells a variety of men’s, women’s, and children’s undergarments. Marcia is dedicated to the success of her business as she dreams of one day owning her own large variety store and converting a room in her house to a store. Loan funds will be used to increase current inventory levels and begin the process of creating a store. On behalf of Esperanza and this group of business entrepreneurs, we would like to thank you for your support!

loans.use: Purchase new undergarments to refurbish business.
